title: How to Make Blender Muffins

steps.headline: Preheat your oven.
steps.description:
Set your oven for 400°F (204°C) degrees. If your oven doesn’t have a timer to indicate when it’s reached 400°F (204°C) degrees, use an oven thermometer. Just make sure to check the thermometer after five minutes or so to see if it’s ready. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/43\/Make-Blender-Muffins-Step-1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/43\/Make-Blender-Muffins-Step-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":508,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Measure out the ingredients.
steps.description: There are two different ways to make mini blender muffins, one which requires rolled oats and one that uses peanut butter. The recipe with rolled oats will have more of a muffin-like consistency. However, the recipe with peanut butter is simpler and uses only five ingredients. It’s up to you which recipe you’d like to follow! After you’ve measured everything out, mix all the dry ingredients into one bowl for easy pouring. You can also set your extra ingredients or add-ins aside. These are any fruits, nuts, or chocolate that you want to bake in with your muffins.

steps.headline: Put all the ingredients in a blender and mix.
steps.description: You can use a standard blender or a food processor. However, a handheld blender may not work as well. There is no set order to putting ingredients in, but alternating wet and dry items might aid in the mixing process. Once you’ve added everything, blend until the mixture is smooth. This should take one to two minutes.

steps.headline: Prepare and fill the muffin tins.
steps.description: Take a basic 12-piece mini-muffin tin and line each cup with parchment paper or cupcake liners. If you don’t have either of these, you can also spray the cupcake tin with cooking spray or oil. Once prepared, fill each cup with a portion of the muffin batter. As the muffins will rise while baking, try to fill each tin only halfway.

steps.headline: Add in extra ingredients.
steps.description: Depending on the type of muffin you want, you can add-in whatever ingredients you like. For example, if you want blueberry muffins, stick a couple of blueberries into each portion of batter. You can also add chocolate chips, almonds, strawberries, apple slices, or just cinnamon. Or, if you want a little bit of everything, alternate ingredients throughout each cup. It’s up to you!

steps.headline: Bake the muffins.
steps.description: Once the oven is at 400°F (204°C) degrees, place the muffin tin in the center of the rack. Bake the muffins for around eight to ten minutes. Baking time can vary depending on the oven, so be sure to check your muffins by sticking a toothpick or fork in them. If you see muffin batter on the items when you pull them out, then your muffins need to cook longer.

steps.headline: Let the muffins cool.
steps.description: Once you’ve removed the muffins from the oven, leave them in their muffin tin to cool. This should take about five or six minutes. After that, feel free to remove the muffins from the tin and place them on a plate or platter. The muffins should also be ready for eating at this time.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven.
steps.description:
Set your oven for 400°F (204°C) degrees before you start mixing ingredients. This should take about five to ten minutes. However, if your oven doesn’t have a timer to indicate that it’s ready, try using an oven thermometer. You will have to check the thermometer before baking, but you will get a more accurate temperature reading than just guessing. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/9\/96\/Make-Blender-Muffins-Step-8.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/9\/96\/Make-Blender-Muffins-Step-8.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":508,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Measure out and double the ingredients.
steps.description: You can make muffins using either rolled oats or peanut butter, but for regular sized muffins you will have to double the ingredients. For example, to make regular muffins with rolled oats, you need two cups of oats, two bananas, two eggs, one cup of Greek yogurt, and so on. The same would apply for regular sized muffins made with peanut butter. Set aside all add-ins like blueberries, coconut flakes, chocolate chips, almonds, mango, pineapple, and strawberries.

steps.headline: Add each ingredient to your blender and mix.
steps.description: As you measure out each ingredient, put them into a standard blender or food processor. The order you add them doesn’t matter, but try alternating wet and dry for better mixing. Make sure to only add the first set of ingredients, though, as the add-ins like blueberries, chocolate chips, and almonds will be put in later. Once every item has been put in, blend the mixture for one to two minutes until smooth.

steps.headline: Pour the batter into a regular muffin tin.
steps.description: Before filling your muffin tin, make sure to line each cup with a cupcake liner or piece of parchment. You can also use cooking spray or oil to coat the cups and prevent sticking. After this, pour batter into each cup in the tray until they’re 3/4th full, as the muffins will rise.

steps.headline: Add in any extras.
steps.description: After all the batter has been portioned out, start adding any additional ingredients you want. For example, if you want chocolate chip muffins, put a couple of chocolate chips into each cup of batter. Or if you want blueberry cinnamon, place two to three blueberries into each mixture and sprinkle them with a pinch of cinnamon. You can also alternate inclusions if you want a bit of everything.

steps.headline: Bake the muffins.
steps.description: Once your oven has hit 400°F (204°C) degrees, place the muffin tin into the center of the rack. The muffins should bake 15 minutes or so depending on your oven. To be sure they are baking through and not being over baked, check the muffins about five minutes in. You can insert a toothpick or fork to see if the batter is baking properly. If either item comes back wet with batter, then the muffins need longer.

steps.headline: Let the muffins cool.
steps.description: Once they’ve finished baking, the muffins will need to rest and cool for five to six minutes. You can leave the muffins in their tin for this. However, after they have cooled, feel free to move them to a different plate or platter. You can also eat them if you like.

text:
Making Mini-Muffins Preheat your oven. Set your oven for 400°F (204°C) degrees. If your oven doesn’t have a timer to indicate when it’s reached 400°F (204°C) degrees, use an oven thermometer. Just make sure to check the thermometer after five minutes or so to see if it’s ready. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/43/Make-Blender-Muffins-Step-1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/43/Make-Blender-Muffins-Step-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":508,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Measure out the ingredients. There are two different ways to make mini blender muffins, one which requires rolled oats and one that uses peanut butter. The recipe with rolled oats will have more of a muffin-like consistency. However, the recipe with peanut butter is simpler and uses only five ingredients. It’s up to you which recipe you’d like to follow! After you’ve measured everything out, mix all the dry ingredients into one bowl for easy pouring. You can also set your extra ingredients or add-ins aside. These are any fruits, nuts, or chocolate that you want to bake in with your muffins. Put all the ingredients in a blender and mix. You can use a standard blender or a food processor. However, a handheld blender may not work as well. There is no set order to putting ingredients in, but alternating wet and dry items might aid in the mixing process. Once you’ve added everything, blend until the mixture is smooth. This should take one to two minutes. Prepare and fill the muffin tins. Take a basic 12-piece mini-muffin tin and line each cup with parchment paper or cupcake liners. If you don’t have either of these, you can also spray the cupcake tin with cooking spray or oil. Once prepared, fill each cup with a portion of the muffin batter. As the muffins will rise while baking, try to fill each tin only halfway. Add in extra ingredients. Depending on the type of muffin you want, you can add-in whatever ingredients you like. For example, if you want blueberry muffins, stick a couple of blueberries into each portion of batter. You can also add chocolate chips, almonds, strawberries, apple slices, or just cinnamon. Or, if you want a little bit of everything, alternate ingredients throughout each cup. It’s up to you! Bake the muffins. Once the oven is at 400°F (204°C) degrees, place the muffin tin in the center of the rack. Bake the muffins for around eight to ten minutes. Baking time can vary depending on the oven, so be sure to check your muffins by sticking a toothpick or fork in them. If you see muffin batter on the items when you pull them out, then your muffins need to cook longer. Let the muffins cool. Once you’ve removed the muffins from the oven, leave them in their muffin tin to cool. This should take about five or six minutes. After that, feel free to remove the muffins from the tin and place them on a plate or platter. The muffins should also be ready for eating at this time. Making Full-Sized Muffins Preheat your oven. Set your oven for 400°F (204°C) degrees before you start mixing ingredients. This should take about five to ten minutes. However, if your oven doesn’t have a timer to indicate that it’s ready, try using an oven thermometer. You will have to check the thermometer before baking, but you will get a more accurate temperature reading than just guessing. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/9/96/Make-Blender-Muffins-Step-8.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/9/96/Make-Blender-Muffins-Step-8.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":508,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Measure out and double the ingredients. You can make muffins using either rolled oats or peanut butter, but for regular sized muffins you will have to double the ingredients. For example, to make regular muffins with rolled oats, you need two cups of oats, two bananas, two eggs, one cup of Greek yogurt, and so on. The same would apply for regular sized muffins made with peanut butter. Set aside all add-ins like blueberries, coconut flakes, chocolate chips, almonds, mango, pineapple, and strawberries. Add each ingredient to your blender and mix. As you measure out each ingredient, put them into a standard blender or food processor. The order you add them doesn’t matter, but try alternating wet and dry for better mixing. Make sure to only add the first set of ingredients, though, as the add-ins like blueberries, chocolate chips, and almonds will be put in later. Once every item has been put in, blend the mixture for one to two minutes until smooth. Pour the batter into a regular muffin tin. Before filling your muffin tin, make sure to line each cup with a cupcake liner or piece of parchment. You can also use cooking spray or oil to coat the cups and prevent sticking. After this, pour batter into each cup in the tray until they’re 3/4th full, as the muffins will rise. Add in any extras. After all the batter has been portioned out, start adding any additional ingredients you want. For example, if you want chocolate chip muffins, put a couple of chocolate chips into each cup of batter. Or if you want blueberry cinnamon, place two to three blueberries into each mixture and sprinkle them with a pinch of cinnamon. You can also alternate inclusions if you want a bit of everything. Bake the muffins. Once your oven has hit 400°F (204°C) degrees, place the muffin tin into the center of the rack. The muffins should bake 15 minutes or so depending on your oven. To be sure they are baking through and not being over baked, check the muffins about five minutes in. You can insert a toothpick or fork to see if the batter is baking properly. If either item comes back wet with batter, then the muffins need longer. Let the muffins cool. Once they’ve finished baking, the muffins will need to rest and cool for five to six minutes. You can leave the muffins in their tin for this. However, after they have cooled, feel free to move them to a different plate or platter. You can also eat them if you like.
sentences: Making Mini-Muffins Preheat your oven.
Set your oven for 400°F (204°C) degrees.
If your oven doesn’t have a timer to indicate when it’s reached 400°F (204°C) degrees, use an oven thermometer.
Just make sure to check the thermometer after five minutes or so to see if it’s ready.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/43\/Make-Blender-Muffins-Step-1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/43\/Make-Blender-Muffins-Step-1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":508,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Measure out the ingredients.
There are two different ways to make mini blender muffins, one which requires rolled oats and one that uses peanut butter.
The recipe with rolled oats will have more of a muffin-like consistency.
However, the recipe with peanut butter is simpler and uses only five ingredients.
It’s up to you which recipe you’d like to follow!
After you’ve measured everything out, mix all the dry ingredients into one bowl for easy pouring.
You can also set your extra ingredients or add-ins aside.
These are any fruits, nuts, or chocolate that you want to bake in with your muffins.
Put all the ingredients in a blender and mix.
You can use a standard blender or a food processor.
However, a handheld blender may not work as well.
There is no set order to putting ingredients in, but alternating wet and dry items might aid in the mixing process.
Once you’ve added everything, blend until the mixture is smooth.
This should take one to two minutes.
Prepare and fill the muffin tins.
Take a basic 12-piece mini-muffin tin and line each cup with parchment paper or cupcake liners.
If you don’t have either of these, you can also spray the cupcake tin with cooking spray or oil.
Once prepared, fill each cup with a portion of the muffin batter.
As the muffins will rise while baking, try to fill each tin only halfway.
Add in extra ingredients.
Depending on the type of muffin you want, you can add-in whatever ingredients you like.
For example, if you want blueberry muffins, stick a couple of blueberries into each portion of batter.
You can also add chocolate chips, almonds, strawberries, apple slices, or just cinnamon.
Or, if you want a little bit of everything, alternate ingredients throughout each cup.
It’s up to you!
Bake the muffins.
Once the oven is at 400°F (204°C) degrees, place the muffin tin in the center of the rack.
Bake the muffins for around eight to ten minutes.
Baking time can vary depending on the oven, so be sure to check your muffins by sticking a toothpick or fork in them.
If you see muffin batter on the items when you pull them out, then your muffins need to cook longer.
Let the muffins cool.
Once you’ve removed the muffins from the oven, leave them in their muffin tin to cool.
This should take about five or six minutes.
After that, feel free to remove the muffins from the tin and place them on a plate or platter.
The muffins should also be ready for eating at this time.
Making Full-Sized Muffins Preheat your oven.
Set your oven for 400°F (204°C) degrees before you start mixing ingredients.
This should take about five to ten minutes.
However, if your oven doesn’t have a timer to indicate that it’s ready, try using an oven thermometer.
You will have to check the thermometer before baking, but you will get a more accurate temperature reading than just guessing.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/9\/96\/Make-Blender-Muffins-Step-8.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/9\/96\/Make-Blender-Muffins-Step-8.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":508,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Measure out and double the ingredients.
You can make muffins using either rolled oats or peanut butter, but for regular sized muffins you will have to double the ingredients.
For example, to make regular muffins with rolled oats, you need two cups of oats, two bananas, two eggs, one cup of Greek yogurt, and so on.
The same would apply for regular sized muffins made with peanut butter.
Set aside all add-ins like blueberries, coconut flakes, chocolate chips, almonds, mango, pineapple, and strawberries.
Add each ingredient to your blender and mix.
As you measure out each ingredient, put them into a standard blender or food processor.
The order you add them doesn’t matter, but try alternating wet and dry for better mixing.
Make sure to only add the first set of ingredients, though, as the add-ins like blueberries, chocolate chips, and almonds will be put in later.
Once every item has been put in, blend the mixture for one to two minutes until smooth.
Pour the batter into a regular muffin tin.
Before filling your muffin tin, make sure to line each cup with a cupcake liner or piece of parchment.
You can also use cooking spray or oil to coat the cups and prevent sticking.
After this, pour batter into each cup in the tray until they’re 3/4th full, as the muffins will rise.
Add in any extras.
After all the batter has been portioned out, start adding any additional ingredients you want.
For example, if you want chocolate chip muffins, put a couple of chocolate chips into each cup of batter.
Or if you want blueberry cinnamon, place two to three blueberries into each mixture and sprinkle them with a pinch of cinnamon.
You can also alternate inclusions if you want a bit of everything.
Bake the muffins.
Once your oven has hit 400°F (204°C) degrees, place the muffin tin into the center of the rack.
The muffins should bake 15 minutes or so depending on your oven.
To be sure they are baking through and not being over baked, check the muffins about five minutes in.
You can insert a toothpick or fork to see if the batter is baking properly.
If either item comes back wet with batter, then the muffins need longer.
Let the muffins cool.
Once they’ve finished baking, the muffins will need to rest and cool for five to six minutes.
You can leave the muffins in their tin for this.
However, after they have cooled, feel free to move them to a different plate or platter.
You can also eat them if you like.
